question: Test shown in the video is for which structure & its nerve supply:
exp: Test shown in the video is for Supraspinatus (C5, C6) Empty can test: This tests the strength of Supraspinatus. The patient is asked to raise his /her arms to a position of 90-degree abduction, 30 degrees of forward flexion and internal rotation(thumbs pointing to the floor, as if emptying an imaginary can) The examiner stands behind the patient and applies downward pressure on both arms, with the patient resisting this force. The result is positive if the affected side is weaker than the unaffected side-tear of the supraspinatus tendon.

question: Following an incised wound in the front of wrist, the subject is unable to oppose the tips of the little finger and the thumb. The nerve(s) involved is/are:
exp: The patient has inability to oppose little finger (paralysis of opponens digiti minimi) and oppose thumb (paralysis of opponens pollicis). So, both ulnar and median nerves are paralysed.

question: Given video shows findings of an abnormality. The patient has most likely suffered lesion at which level?
exp: Low Radial nerve palsy: Injury is before the spiral groove. All muscles supplied by radial nerve are paralysed. Low radial nerve injuries may be of two types:- 1) Type 1: Injury occurs between the spiral groove and elbow joint. Muscles involved is:- Elbow extensors(Triceps, Anconeus) are spared. Wrist, elbow and finger extensors are paralysed. Sensory loss in first web space(on dorsal side). 2). Type 2:-Injury occurs below the elbow joint. Elbow extensors, brachioradialis and wrist extensors(ECRL)are spared. Finger extensors (extensor digitorum, extensor digiti minimi, extensor indicis), ECRB and thumb extensors(extensor pollicis longus & brevis)are paralysed. Sensory loss in the first web space(on dorsal side).

question: A patient can't extend his wrist after he has met with an accident. He has no sensory loss. Level at which the affected nerve is injured?
exp: Patient has wrist drop so radial nerve is involved, there can be sensory sparing in radial nerve injury.

question: In 3-year-child with polio paralysis, tendon transfer operation is done at:
exp: Tendon transfers: Done to equalise an unbalanced paralysis or to use the motor power of working muscles for more useful functions. Not done before 5 years of age as the child has to be manageable enough to be taught proper exercises. As the child is 3 years old, tendon transfer should be done after 2 years (at 5 years of age).

question: Which of the following is not a good prognosis?
exp: GOOD NERVE G- growing age/good repair O-only motor involvement O- only sensory involvement D- distal lesion N- Neuropraxia E- early repair R - radial nerve injury V- vascularity maintained E- end to end repair

question: Brachial plexus injury with Horner's syndrome, nerve root level involved is:
exp: - Horner syndrome is due to involvement of white matter of spinal cord at T1 level. " Klumpke's palsy: Occurs in lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8-T1) Claw hand is present due to the paralysis of intrinsic muscles of hand It is associated with Horner's syndrome Has poor prognosis

question: Cock up splint is used for which nerve injury?
exp: High radial nerve injury - brachioradialis paralyzed+ wrist drop + finger drop + sensory loss Low radial nerve injury - wrist drop + finger drop + sensory loss ( brachioradialis is spared) PIN injury - finger drop + sensory loss Superficial - sensory loss -Splints used in other nerve injuries: Brachial plexus injury- Aeroplane splint Ulnar nerve > Median nerve- Knuckle bender splint

question: Road traffic accident, a patient lying in right lateral position with bruise on face, elbow and lateral side of knee. Which nerve injury has maximum chances in this position of the victim?
exp: Amongst the mentioned nerves most frequently injured nerve in lateral position will be the nerve that has maximum chances of injury due to compression against a bony prominence and that is common peroneal nerve near fibular neck.

question: Tendon used for repair of flexor tendon injury in hand requiring reconstruction from forearm to fingeip is:
exp: Tendons used for reconstruction Palmaris longus--Hand to fingeip Plantaris--Forearm to fingeip (plantaris is longest tendon in the body)

question: You have noticed ape like thumb in a 30 years young man from bihar who is a known patient of leprosy? Which of the following test is not done to show the nerve involved in this condition?
exp: Common in leprosy-The involvement of the: median nerve at the wrist ulnar nerve at the elbow common peroneal nerve at the fibular head Here median nerve (C5-T1) is involved all other tests done for median nerve palsy Card test is done for ulnar nerve A high/proximal lesion of the median nerve manifests in the hand of benediction

question: Axillary nerve injury likely to be seen in:
exp: Axillary nerve is damaged due to the following causes: Shoulder dislocation(anterior/inferior) Fracture of upper end of Humerus Injection into deltoid muscle
